Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA)

Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: Strengthening 
Water Sector Management and Service Delivery  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) will help to achieve and sustain the expected 
impact and outcome of the District Capitals Water Supply Project.1 The TA will provide water 
sector officials at the national level and in Manatuto and Pante Macasar with the capacity and 
institutional reforms needed to effectively manage, operate, and maintain urban water supply 
systems and ensure the technical and financial sustainability of those systems. The government 
agreed on the need for sector institutional reforms on 8 November 2011 and endorsed the TA 
on  24  November  2011.2  The  impact,  outcome,  and  expected  outputs  agreed  with  the 
government are included in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The strategy for water supply and sanitation included in the government’s Strategic 
Development Plan 2011–2030 lists providing safe, piped 24-hour water supply to households in 
12 district centers as one of the three sector priorities.3 In line with the sector priorities of the 
government, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for 
Timor-Leste  lists  as  the  outcome  for  the  sector  the  expansion  of  safe  water  supply  and 
sanitation  services  in  urban  areas,  focusing  on  increasing  management  efficiency  of  the 
systems. 4 
 
3.  Responsibility for operation and maintenance (O&M) of Timor-Leste’s 13 urban water 
supply schemes lies with the National Directorate for Water Supply and Sanitation (NDWSS),5 a 
division of the Ministry of Infrastructure (MOI). Although established with a strategic plan and 
organizational structure suited to expected corporatization, the NDWSS continues to operate as 
a  government  ministry.  It  has  limited  autonomy  in  decision  making,  other  than  for  basic 
operational matters, and exhibits little accountability to its customers. All financing, fees and 
charges,  staffing,  infrastructure  development,  and  procurement  decisions  require  the  prior 
approval of higher-level government agencies. The NDWSS acts under the oversight of the 
secretary  of  state  within  the  MOI,  and  water  supply  legislation  makes  no  provision  for 
independent  economic  or  technical  oversight  by  a  regulatory  body  or  for  consumer 
accountability. The NDWSS largely self-regulates its levels of service and operational efficiency. 
 
4.  Substantial development partner assistance has been provided to the NDWSS since 
2007 to help build capacity, including the Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Project and the TA 
4869-TIM: Dili Water Supply Performance Improvement.6 However, the capacity of the NDWSS

of Infrastructure (MOI) and NDWSS.

to plan, manage, and operate water supply systems and to develop and implement water sector 
policies, while improving, remains weak. The capacity of the NDWSS to operate and maintain 
urban water supplies is also constrained by limited annual budgets to fund O&M. Consequently, 
maintenance  is  reactive,  planned  asset  maintenance  programs  are  not  implemented,  and 
system functionality and service quality are declining.7  
 
5.  ADB-funded interventions in Timor-Leste8 have validated the need to improve O&M of 
water systems and to increase institutional capacity to manage urban water supply systems. 
These improvements are vital preconditions to adequate service delivery  which cannot be 
compensated by infrastructure investment alone. A different operational mode with an effective 
O&M strategy is required for Timor-Leste to meet its water sector development goals. Previous 
TA has focused on changing the management structure of the NDWSS without addressing the 
constraints posed by the existing regulatory and institutional framework. Within the current 
framework, the NDWSS does not have the mandate to implement the proposed management 
structures and procedural changes.   
 
6.  The District Capitals Water Supply Project outcome is for NDWSS to provide safe and 
reliable water supply to district capitals—Manatuto and Pante Macasar. However, to ensure the 
technical and financial sustainability of the water supply systems rehabilitated under the project,  
the MOI will have to implement institutional reforms to allow the NDWSS to make changes to its 
technical  and  financial  management  structure.  The  TA  will  support  the  development  and 
implementation of an institutional reform program to facilitate changes in NDWSS management 
that will ensure that financial and human resources to the District Department for Water Supply 
and Sanitation (DDWSS) are sufficient to operate and maintain urban water supply systems. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA will contribute to achieving universal access by urban households in Manatuto 
and Pante Macasar to safe, piped 24-hour water supply. The outcome of the TA is that MOI and 
NDWSS will implement a tested urban water sector institutional reform program. The outputs of 
the TA will be the (i) adoption of an urban water sector institutional reform program by MOI and 
NDWSS,  and  (ii)  successful  implementation  of  the  proposed  NDWSS  urban  water  sector 
institutional reform program in Pante Macasar and Manatuto. In developing the TA, the following 
assumptions have been made: (i) the government will support the reforms, (ii) the MOI and 
NDWSS continue to support the role of DDWSS staff in the districts, and (iii) trained personnel 
are not transferred to another district after the TA completion. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  At the national level, existing institutional assessments to improve water supply policy 
and  service  delivery  will  be  reviewed,  and  work  will  be  undertaken  with  the  MOI  on  the 
                                                                                                                                                       
Improvement. Manila. (TA 4869-TIM, $1.0 million approved on 17 December).  TA activities commenced on 29 
June 2008 and were completed in December 2010.

institutional reforms needed to finalize and implement the existing draft water supply policy. 
Coordination with the Ministry of Finance and MOI will ensure that the urban water reforms 
support the government’s draft public–private partnerships policy. At the same time, the TA will 
work closely with the NDWSS to ensure that (i) the proposed reforms address the capacity 
building plans that were produced during the participatory assessment carried out under the TA 
Results Based Project Management for the Pacific Developing Member Countries, and (ii) 
technical and management skills in the NDWSS increase. The key output of these activities will 
be that national and district water sector officials agree to and adopt the proposed urban water 
sector institutional reform program. 
 
9.  At  the  same time,  the TA  will  work  with  local  institutions  in the  district  capitals  of 
Manatuto and Pante Macasar to ensure that (i) stakeholders and communities participate in 
national policy discussions, and (ii) the proposed reforms can be implemented locally. Support 
will be provided to the DDWSS, district and local administrations, and local communities to (i) 
discuss and provide feedback on the proposed national reforms and their implications for the 
delivery of services at the district level, (ii) develop and adopt a detailed strategy for the 
implementation of the proposed reforms in the two towns, and (iii) test the implementation of the 
proposed reforms in Manatuto and Pante Macasar. The outcome of these activities will be that 
Pante Macasar DDWSS and Manatuto DDWSS successfully test the proposed urban water 
sector institutional reform program. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.2 million. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government contribution will consist 
of counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, transport, and remuneration of 
counterpart staff. Detailed cost estimates are provided in Appendix 2. The proceeds of the TA 
will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 32 months and is expected to commence 
on July 2012. The TA will provide support at the national and local levels. The MOI will be the 
executing agency for the TA and will be the leading agency for the outputs related to national 
policy and institutional reforms. The MOI role will include appointing a high-level committee to 
agree on institutional reform and a strategy to implement it at the national level. The NDWSS 
will be the leading implementing agency for testing the agreed institutional reforms in Manatuto 
and Pante Macasar. The project management unit providing support to ADB water sector 
projects9 will provide support to the TA consultants in aspects such as financial management, 
monitoring,  and  procurement.  For  workshops,  training  and  seminars,  and  conferences,  an 
advance payment facility may be used. 
 
12.  ADB will recruit six individual consultants for a total of 32 person-months of international 
services and 63 person-months of national services (Appendix 3) to (i) develop the urban water 
sector institutional reform program in partnership with the government, the private sector, and 
community  stakeholders;  and  (ii)  provide  on-the-job  and  external  training  to  water  sector

officials. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) and all procurement will be done in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
13.  Under the TA, the Timor-Leste urban water sector institutional reform program and 
training  manuals  will  be  produced  from  the  capacity  building  activities.  These  knowledge 
products will be disseminated widely to water sector stakeholders and donors during a final 
workshop.  The  results  and  outcomes  of  the  TA  will  be  reported  to  ADB  through  these 
knowledge products and ongoing monitoring by the ADB project team leader. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Timor-Leste  for  Strengthening Water  Sector  Management  and  Service 
Delivery, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consultant Outputs 
 
1.    Urban Water Sector Institutional Reform Program 
 
1.    An inception report will be submitted that includes the following sections: 
 
(i)  a brief analysis of the main stakeholders in the water sector; 
(ii)  a summary of existing literature to improve the National Directorate for Water 
Supply and  Sanitation (NDWSS) management including corporate plans and 
capacity building plans for NDWSS developed under Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) Dili Water Supply Performance Improvement Project and Results-Based 
Project Management for Pacific Developing Member Countries;1 
(iii)  a summary of preliminary consultations with the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of 
Infrastructure,  NDWSS,  Ministry  of  Local  Development  and  Planning,  district 
administrators of Manatuto and Oecusse, and secretary of state for Oecusse; 
and 
(iv)  based on preliminary consultations, recommendations for possible institutional 
arrangements and two or three scenarios with an analysis of pros and cons for 
each of them. 
 
2.  The report will be translated into Tetum and discussed in an interim workshop with the 
main stakeholders. During this workshop, one of the proposed scenarios will be selected. 
 
3.  Based on the conclusions of the interim workshop, a report describing the proposed draft 
urban water sector institutional reform program will be produced, and will detail 
(i)  the institutional arrangement for the urban water sector, with the functions and 
mandates of each stakeholder and the estimated budget and staffing required to 
carry out those functions; 
(ii)  how the proposed program addresses cost recovery, performance management, 
capacity development, and funding for technical operation and maintenance of 
urban systems (including technical losses); 
(iii)  a schedule and key activities for the implementation of the reform program, 
including the responsibilities of each agency for successful implementation; 
(iv)  a description of the type of contractual arrangements recommended for urban 
water supply systems with a draft contract for the towns of Manatuto and Pante 
Macasar (if public–private partnerships are included in the program); 
(v)  a draft of any regulatory changes required for implementation of the reform 
program; and 
(vi)  specific implementation arrangements for Manatuto and Pante Macasar. 
 
4.  The report will be translated into Tetum and provided to all stakeholders. 
 
2.  Training and Technical Support to National Directorate for Water Supply 
and Sanitation and District Department for Water Supply and Sanitation

B.  Consulting Services 
 
1.  Water Utility Management Specialist and Team Leader (international, 16 
person-months, intermittent) 
 
7.  The water utility management specialist and team leader will have at least 10 years of 
experience in the management of urban water utilities, of which at least 3 years will be in 
developing countries. Areas of water sector management expertise will include O&M systems, 
business  planning,  performance  management,  human  resources  management,  asset 
management, water resources management, and financial management. He or she will be 
fluent in Tetum or Bahasa Indonesia. 
 
8.  The water utility management specialist and team leader will: 
 
(i)  prepare a detailed work plan for the consulting team and prepare all results and 
financial reports for submission to ADB; 
(ii)  review good practices in urban water supply asset management and operation 
and maintenance (O&M), and previous assessments and technical assistance of 
the Timor-Leste urban water sector; 
(iii)  work with the institutional change facilitation specialist to prepare a consultation 
and participation plan to garner stakeholder input into the design of the proposed 
urban water sector institutional reform program; 
(iv)  incorporate results of the national policy discussions, draft the urban water sector 
institutional  reform  program  including  the  following  components:  sector 
organizational  structure,  roles  and  responsibilities  (including  public–private 
partnerships),  human  resources  management  (including  performance 
incentives),  customer  service  system  and  procedures,  financial  management 
system (including billing, cash flow management, tariff reintroduction plan, and 
accessibility provisions), water quality and flow testing procedures, O&M systems 
and  procedures,  asset  management  plan,  and  a  5-year  business  plan  and 
budget; 
(v)  work with government agencies in the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Finance 
to  develop  specific  contractual  arrangements to  improve  performance  of  the 
water  sector  (if  public–private  partnerships  are  included  in  the  proposed 
program); 
(vi)  assess the training needs of the NDWSS and the two DDWSSs to implement the 
proposed urban water sector institutional reform program, and design and deliver 
training programs and manuals to fill identified training needs; 
(vii)  provide on-the-job training and technical support on management issues for the 
NDWSS and DDWSSs; with stakeholders, evaluate the success of the piloting of 
the urban water sector institutional reform program and revise the program to 
incorporate lessons learned; 
(viii)  design the national roll-out of the tested urban water sector institutional reform 
program;

2.  Water Utility Management Specialist and Deputy Team Leader (national, 30 
person-months) 
 
9.  The water utility management specialist and deputy team leader will have at least 5 
years of experience in the water sector in Timor-Leste, strong facilitation and coordination skills, 
and proficiency in English. 
 
10.  The water utility management specialist and deputy team leader will: 
  
(i)  build rapport with the MOI and NDWSS and ensure stakeholders are leading 
technical assistance (TA) activities;   
(ii)  coordinate  with  the  team  leader,  O&M  specialist,  and  water  supply  finance 
specialist in preparing the training needs assessment and designing training 
programs; 
(iii)  provide training to the NDWSS and DDWSS in those areas of expertise as 
required by the team leader; 
(iv)  work with the team leader in implementing and evaluating the piloting of the 
urban water sector institutional reform program and the design of its national roll-
out; and 
(v)  report to the team leader. 
 
3.  Institutional Change Facilitation Specialist (national, 29 person-months) 
 
11.  The  institutional  change  facilitation  specialist  will  have  extensive  experience  in 
designing, conducting, and evaluating participatory  exercises, using a variety of modalities 
including workshops, forums, public awareness campaigns, and interactive training programs. 
He or she will be familiar with water sector issues and major stakeholders in Timor-Leste and 
speak and write English and Tetum. 
 
12.  The institutional change facilitation specialist will: 
 
(i)  build rapport with the MOI and NDWSS and ensure stakeholders are leading TA 
activities;   
(ii)  work with the team leader in preparing reports, and managing and facilitating TA 
activities and inputs of the consulting team, as required by the team leader; 
(iii)  coordinate  with  the  team  leader  and  deputy  team  leader  to  prepare  a 
consultation and participation plan to garner stakeholder input into the design of 
the proposed urban water sector institutional reform program; 
(iv)  coordinate  TA  activities  with  the  activities  of  other  major  water  sector 
stakeholders  and  development  partners,  and  participate  in  partners’  policy 
discussion events and workshops to gather information relevant to the TA; 
(v)  design  and  facilitate  national  policy  forums  and  design  workshops  on  the 
proposed program; 
(vi)  work with the team leader to design and facilitate interactive training workshops 
and on-the-job training and mentoring sessions;

(ix)  translate  reports  and  communication  materials  into  Tetum  for  distribution  to

4.  Water Supply Finance Specialist (international, 5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
13.  The water supply finance specialist will have formal finance and economics qualifications 
and at least 10 years of experience in preparing financial and economic analyses of urban water 
infrastructure projects, undertaking financial performance assessments, and designing financial 
management systems for the urban water sector. 
 
14.  The water supply finance specialist will: 
 
(i)  collect data on the current costs (direct and indirect) of urban water sector O&M 
and of existing assets; 
(ii)  assess  the  existing  tariff  structures  for  urban  water  supply  and  identify 
amendments to tariff structures to improve cost recovery and sustainability of 
services while supporting access to urban water supply by all households; 
(iii)  identify financial mechanisms suitable to Timor-Leste to operate, maintain, and 
replace urban water sector infrastructure; 
(iv)  hold meetings with the NDWSS, MOI, and Ministry of Finance on the findings of 
his or her activities and discuss proposed scenarios; 
(v)  propose a financial management system, including cash flow procedures, for the 
urban water sector; 
(vi)  support and assist the team leader, as required, in preparing the proposed and 
tested urban water sector institutional reform programs; 
(vii)  support and assist the institutional change facilitation specialist, as required, in 
discussions of financial issues during national policy discussions and design 
workshops;  
(viii)  provide on-the-job training for a period of at least 2 months on financial issues, 
as required by the team leader; and 
(ix)  report to the team leader. 
 
5.  Operations and Maintenance Specialist (international, 11 person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
15.  The operations and maintenance specialist will have formal water supply engineering or 
equivalent qualifications and at least 10 years of experience in the operation and maintenance 
of urban water supply systems, preferably with experience in mentoring and training programs 
and team management. He or she will be fluent in Tetum or Bahasa Indonesia. 
 
16.  The operations and maintenance specialist will: 
 
(i)  in coordination with the District Capitals Water Supply Project implementation 
unit,  provide  mentoring  and  on-the-job  training  to  NDWSS,  Pante  Macasar 
DDWSS,  and  Manatuto  DDWSS  officials  with  regard  to  the  day-to-day

12       Appendix 3     
operations, systems, and procedures of the NDWSS, Pante Macasar DDWSS, 
and Manatuto DDWSS;  
(ii)  provide technical advice to the NDWSS operations and maintenance department 
as required by the NDWSS; 
(iii)  assist the team in developing the institutional reform program to improve existing 
O&M of urban water supply systems in accordance with manuals prepared under 
the District Capitals Water Supply Project; 
(iv)  work with the water supply finance specialist to identify the optimal level of 
financial  and  human  resources  needed  for  O&M  of  the  Timor-Leste  urban 
systems; and  
(v)  report to the team leader. 
 
6.  Legal Draftsperson (national, 4 person-months, intermittent) 
 
17.  The legal draftsperson will have 5–10 years of experience in reviewing and drafting 
regulations and a degree in law from a recognized university. 
 
18.  The legal draftsperson will: 
 
(i)  identify gaps in the legal frameworks and regulations relevant to the urban water 
sector (including finance and procurement regulations); 
(ii)  support and assist the team leader, as required, in preparing the proposed and 
tested urban water sector institutional reform programs; 
(iii)  support and assist the institutional change facilitation specialist, as required, in 
discussions  of  legal  issues  during  national  policy  discussions  and  design 
workshops; 
(iv)  provide training on legal issues, as required by the team leader;  
(v)  prepare  draft  regulations  for  filling  legislative  gaps  to  upgrade  legislative 
frameworks to support implementation of the urban water sector institutional 
reform program; and 
(vi)  report to the team leader.
